qas.question: How did the British avoid having large contingents of troops in continental Europe?

answers.text: allying themselves with one or more Continental powers whose interests were antithetical to those of their enemies,

qas.question: Identify an advantage that Britain had during the Seven Year's War.

answers.text: Britain could turn London's enormous financial power to military advantage

qas.question: Who led the armies supporting British interests in central Europe?
What country was driven into an alliance with France by the British pairing with Prussia?

answers.text: leaving Austria to side with France

qas.question: How did the British behave in defending their colonies compared to the French approach?

answers.text: In marked contrast to France, Britain strove to prosecute the war actively in the colonies

context: The British—by inclination as well as for practical reasons—had tended to avoid large-scale commitments of troops on the Continent. They sought to offset the disadvantage of this in Europe by <a0_0>allying themselves with one or more Continental powers whose interests were antithetical to those of their enemies,<a0_0/> particularly France.:15–16 By subsidising the armies of continental allies, <a1_0>Britain could turn London's enormous financial power to military advantage<a1_0/>. In the Seven Years' War, the British chose as their principal partner the greatest general of the day, <a2_0>Frederick the Great of Prussia<a2_0/>, then the rising power in central Europe, and paid Frederick substantial subsidies for his campaigns.:106 This was accomplished in the Diplomatic Revolution of 1756, in which Britain ended its long-standing alliance with Austria in favor of Prussia, <a3_0>leaving Austria to side with France<a3_0/>. <a4_0>In marked contrast to France, Britain strove to prosecute the war actively in the colonies<a4_0/>, taking full advantage of its naval power. :64–66 The British pursued a dual strategy – naval blockade and bombardment of enemy ports, and rapid movement of troops by sea. They harassed enemy shipping and attacked enemy colonies, frequently using colonists from nearby British colonies in the effort.
